summary: A March 8, 2021 letter from defense attorney Laura A. Menninger of Haddon, Morgan and Foreman to the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, requesting discovery related to FOIA productions concerning the FBI's investigation of Jeffrey Epstein. The letter argues these documents are relevant to Ghislaine Maxwell's defense and questions the government's prior representation about the FBI-New York Office's involvement in the Florida investigation.

persons.name: Laura A. Menninger
persons.context: Attorney from Haddon, Morgan and Foreman representing Ghislaine Maxwell, who writes this discovery request letter to the U.S. Attorney's Office.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in case 20 Cr. 330 (AJN), referenced as the alleged co-conspirator of Jeffrey Epstein. The discovery request is made in relation to her defense.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: Subject of the FBI investigation referenced in the FOIA productions. The documents relate to his investigation and prosecution.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: The judge to whom the government made a representation on October 7, 2020, regarding the prosecution team's lack of involvement in the Florida investigation.

connections.description: Maxwell is described as Epstein's alleged co-conspirator in the document.
Menninger is a defense attorney writing a discovery request on behalf of her client, Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Government's Letter to Judge Nathan
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office represented to Judge Nathan that its prosecution team, including the FBI-New York Office, had no involvement in the Florida investigation of Epstein.

events.title: Requested Deadline for Discovery
events.description: The defense requests the government provide the requested discovery materials by the end of the week, March 15, 2021.

locations: 1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The defense is requesting documents (1,232 pages) the FBI released to Radar Online regarding the investigation of Jeffrey Epstein, arguing they are relevant to Ghislaine Maxwell's defense.
The defense suggests witnesses may have conformed their testimony to publicly released witness statements and police reports, making the timing of the FBI's releases material.
The defense challenges the government's prior statement that the FBI-New York Office had no involvement in the USAO-SDFL (Florida) investigation, citing possible involvement from 2005-2010.
The letter is a formal discovery request under Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 16(a)(1)(E).
